awd_titl_txt: Function and Evolution of Jaw-Muscle Fiber Type in Primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Studying muscle can help us to understand the diets of early humans and other extinct primates. Jaw-muscle fiber types play an important role in fine-tuning the jaw muscles for specific motor tasks such as chewing and powerful biting. This research will study jaw-muscle fiber types across a range of primate species and use those data to test three hypotheses about the evolution of jaw muscle patterns in primates. Results of this work will provide new insights into the relationship between muscle and diet by i) increasing knowledge about the behavioral and ecological factors that shape feeding-system anatomy; ii) advancing our understanding of how jaw-muscle fiber types and whole muscle anatomy work together to generate the jaw movements and jaw forces necessary during feeding and aggressive biting; and (iii) refining models of chewing biomechanics in living and fossil primates. A central component of this work includes the training and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, including women and underrepresented minorities, in state-of-the-art methods for muscle fiber typing.  In addition, results will be incorporated in community outreach programs aimed at exposing primary school girls to science.  Lastly, this project will generate a unique collection of digital images and slides of muscle tissue that will be made available to the scientific community for teaching and research.

The jaw-closing muscles are the motors of the masticatory system.  Collectively, these muscles are responsible for generating the jaw movements and forces associated with feeding behaviors as well as non-feeding oral behaviors such as aggressive biting and wide-mouth opening for canine threat display. While fiber architecture is an important determinant of whole muscle function, its functional and adaptive significance cannot be fully appreciated in the absence of information on fiber type. This lack of data on primate fiber phenotype limits 1) knowledge about variation in jaw-muscle fiber phenotype; 2) the functional significance of this variation for behavior and performance; and 3) the specificity with which we can model and test hypotheses of feeding-system function and performance in both living and fossil species. To provide a more complete framework for linking measures of primate masticatory anatomy and physiology with function and performance, the investigators will collect and analyze novel data on jaw-muscle fiber type composition and distribution in select, closely related species of strepsirrhine and anthropoid primates that diverge in a key feeding or biting behavior. The data collected will be used to: (i) quantify the myosin heavy chain (MHC) fiber type composition and distribution in primate jaw-closing muscles using state-of-the-art immunohistochemistry; (ii) test three key functional and adaptive hypotheses that have been advanced to explain the evolution of fiber phenotype in mammalian jaw muscles:  the frequent recruitment hypothesis, the aggressive bite hypothesis, and the high occlusal force hypothesis; and (iii) assess the correspondence among fiber phenotype, fiber architecture and leverage with the goal of refining models of masticatory biomechanics. This project will provide novel data on the contractile proteins found in primate jaw-closing muscles, advance knowledge of the ecological and behavioral factors that drove changes in the primate jaw-muscle fiber phenotype, and yield new insights into how key components of feeding-system morphology such as fiber architecture, fiber phenotype and leverage combine to facilitate or constrain feeding behavior in primates, including species that have been advanced as models for interpreting feeding behavior and diet in early human ancestors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The chewing muscles are responsible for producing the jaw movements and bite forces associated with feeding. This project aimed to understand the relationship between skeletal muscle fiber types, their functional properties (such as speed of contraction and resistance to fatigue) and how they influence function of the chewing muscles. We identified and classified fibers according to their myosin heavy chain (MHC) protein expression. Using various laboratory methods and statistical analyses, we tested hypotheses about variation in fiber types using different primates as model species.

Several novel and important discoveries were made. First, this work identified the expression and abundance of alpha-cardiac fibers in the chewing muscles of nonhuman primates. These are fatigue resistant fibers like type 1, but they have a speed of contraction that is intermediate between type 1 and type 2 fibers. Second, this work showed that the chewing muscles in primates are dominated by hybrid fiber types—fibers that are a mix of two or more MHC proteins. The amount of hybrid fibers and the number of different hybrid combinations is far greater in primates than has been observed in the chewing muscles of other mammals, including humans. The proportion of hybrid fibers in a muscle or muscle region, combined with the large number of different hybrid combinations, together suggest that primate chewing muscles have a more finely graded continuum of functional properties and a greater degree of flexibility than in other mammals including humans. We further demonstrated a relationship between fiber types and feeding behavior in some primate species. However, this relationship was complicated by the abundance of hybrid fibers. Overall, findings from this work suggest that primates are less specialized in their feeding behaviors than other mammals, that fiber types in primate chewing muscles reflect additional behaviors that do not involve feeding, such as aggressive biting, or both. The expression in primate chewing muscles of a powerful fiber type—type 2M or masticatory myosin—that is not expressed in the chewing muscles of humans, suggests that humans experienced both a diminished capacity for bite force and a loss of flexibility in their chewing muscles sometime during their evolutionary history.

To date, this project has produced multiple peer-reviewed publications and additional papers are in progress. Results of this work have been disseminated at seven national and four international conferences, as well as through invitations to speak at academic seminars and as keynote speakers including graduate student organized research symposia. A children's book was created ("Primates Love to Eat") as an example of how to communicate science to children in grades K-5 and presented at a symposium titled "Un-presentations: Translating Biological Anthropology Research via Creative Expression." Newly generated high-quality images of immunostained muscle sections, staining protocols and novel quantitative data on chewing muscle fiber types in primates have been made publicly available. This project helped build capacity in science, technology, engineering, math, and medicine (STEMM) through training, mentoring and professional development of women and individuals from underrepresented groups, including one high school student and five undergraduate students, as well as several research assistants and one master's student seeking laboratory research experiences in preparation for graduate or medical school. Individuals learned about skeletal muscle physiology and function, received training and mentoring in methods for quantifying and analyzing skeletal muscle fiber types, and presented their results in student research symposia.

 


Last Modified: 04/25/2024
Modified by: Andrea B Taylor
